resource.chars:
While Chamisso’s formula then, expressed 
the truth with regard to the generation of the 
Salpae, it did not express the whole truth 
True it is, that the Salpa solitaria always 
produces the Salpa gregata - & the salpa gregata,
the salpa solitaria; but it is most important 
to remember that the word produce there 
means something very different in the one case 
from what it means in the other - In the 
salpa solitaria the thing produced is a bud;
in the salpa gregata - a true embryo - There 
is no “alternation of generations” if by generation 
sexual generation be meant - but there 
is an <u>alternation of true sexual generation 
with the altogether distinct process of gemmation <\u>
It would be irrelevant to discuss here the 
wide question of the “alternation of generations” 
in all its meanings -
but the writer may be permitted to express his 
belief founded upon many observations upon the Polyps, Acaliphae &c that the phenomena classed under this 
name are always of the same nature as in 
the Salpae; that under no circumstances are 
two forms alternately developed by <u>sexual generation<\u>
but that whereon the so called “alternation of generations 
occurs it is <u>an alternation of generation with gemmation<\u>
Borrowing a comparison from the class of Insects,
the larva never produces the imago by sexual 
generation & the imago, again producing the larva 
by sexual generation - But a pseud-imago 
which is indeed nothing more, homologically, <u>than 
a highly individualised generative organ <\u> is developed from 
the larva - ova are produced by it -
then the larva again is developed - the whole 
process differing from that common to animals in
